For example, server 1230 may distribute the updated autonomous vehicle road navigation model to vehicles 1205, 1210, 1215, 1220, and 1225, which may use the model for navigation. The autonomous vehicle road navigation model may be distributed via one or more networks (e.g., over a cellular network and/or the Internet, etc.), through wireless communication paths 1235, as shown in FIG. 12.

In some embodiments, the lane marks may be mapped using data received from a plurality of vehicles, such as through a crowdsourcing technique, as described above with respect to FIG. 24E. For example, process 2600A may include receiving a first communication from a first host vehicle, including location identifiers associated with a detected lane mark, and receiving a second communication from a second host vehicle, including additional location identifiers associated with the detected lane mark. For example, the second communication may be received from a subsequent vehicle travelling on the same road segment, or from the same vehicle on a subsequent trip along the same road segment. Process 2600A may further include refining a determination of at least one position associated with the detected lane mark based on the location identifiers received in the first communication and based on the additional location identifiers received in the second communication. This may include using an average of the multiple location identifiers and/or filtering out “ghost” identifiers that may not reflect the real-world position of the lane mark.

FIG. 26B is a flowchart showing an exemplary process 2600B for autonomously navigating a host vehicle along a road segment using mapped lane marks. Process 2600B may be performed, for example, by processing unit 110 of autonomous vehicle 200. At step 2620, process 2600B may include receiving from a server-based system an autonomous vehicle road navigation model. In some embodiments, the autonomous vehicle road navigation model may include a target trajectory for the host vehicle along the road segment and location identifiers associated with one or more lane marks associated with the road segment. For example, vehicle 200 may receive sparse map 800 or another road navigation model developed using process 2600A. In some embodiments, the target trajectory may be represented as a three-dimensional spline, for example, as shown in FIG. 9B. As described above with respect to FIGS. 24A-F, the location identifiers may include locations in real world coordinates of points associated with the lane mark (e.g., corner points of a dashed lane mark, edge points of a continuous lane mark, a vertex between two intersecting lane marks and other points associated with the intersecting lane marks, a centerline associated with the lane mark, etc.).

At step 2621, process 2600B may include receiving at least one image representative of an environment of the vehicle. The image may be received from an image capture device of the vehicle, such as through image capture devices 122 and 124 included in image acquisition unit 120. The image may include an image of one or more lane marks, similar to image 2500 described above.

At step 2622, process 2600B may include determining a longitudinal position of the host vehicle along the target trajectory. As described above with respect to FIG. 25A, this may be based on other information in the captured image (e.g., landmarks, etc.) or by dead reckoning of the vehicle between detected landmarks.

At step 2623, process 2600B may include determining an expected lateral distance to the lane mark based on the determined longitudinal position of the host vehicle along the target trajectory and based on the two or more location identifiers associated with the at least one lane mark. For example, vehicle 200 may use sparse map 800 to determine an expected lateral distance to the lane mark. As shown in FIG. 25B, longitudinal position 2520 along a target trajectory 2555 may be determined in step 2622. Using spare map 800, vehicle 200 may determine an expected distance 2540 to mapped lane mark 2550 corresponding to longitudinal position 2520.

At step 2624, process 2600B may include analyzing the at least one image to identify the at least one lane mark. Vehicle 200, for example, may use various image recognition techniques or algorithms to identify the lane mark within the image, as described above. For example, lane mark 2510 may be detected through image analysis of image 2500, as shown in FIG. 25A.

At step 2625, process 2600B may include determining an actual lateral distance to the at least one lane mark based on analysis of the at least one image. For example, the vehicle may determine a distance 2530, as shown in FIG. 25A, representing the actual distance between the vehicle and lane mark 2510. The camera angle, the speed of the vehicle, the width of the vehicle, the position of the camera relative to the vehicle, or various other factors may be accounted for in determining distance 2530.

At step 2626, process 2600B may include determining an autonomous steering action for the host vehicle based on a difference between the expected lateral distance to the at least one lane mark and the determined actual lateral distance to the at least one lane mark. For example, as described above with respect to FIG. 25B, vehicle 200 may compare actual distance 2530 with an expected distance 2544). The difference between the actual and expected distance may indicate an error (and its magnitude) between the vehicle's actual position and the target trajectory to be followed by the vehicle. Accordingly, the vehicle may determine an autonomous steering action or other autonomous action based on the difference. For example, if actual distance 2530 is less than expected distance 2540, as shown in FIG. 25B, the vehicle may determine an autonomous steering action to direct the vehicle left, away from lane mark 2510. Thus, the vehicle's position relative to the target trajectory may be corrected. Process 2600B may be used, for example, to improve navigation of the vehicle between landmarks.
Predicting Blind Spot Incursions

As described above, an autonomous or semiautonomous vehicle may navigate its environment based, in part, on objects detected in its surroundings. For example, a host vehicle may capture images of vehicles and other objects using image capture devices, such as cameras, mounted on the vehicle. In some embodiments, a host vehicle may be equipped with cameras that only partially cover the surroundings of the host vehicle. For example, a host vehicle may have one or more front-facing cameras and rear-facing cameras, which may result in blind spots on the sides of the vehicle that are not within the field of view of the cameras. Even in embodiments where the host vehicle has side-mounted cameras, blind spots may still result due to gaps in camera coverage. Accordingly, a host vehicle may have limited information about vehicles and other objects within one or more blind spots.

The present disclosure provides systems and methods for predicting where an object located behind a host vehicle may be located at a future point in time. For example, a host vehicle may detect an object to the rear of the host vehicle using a camera mounted on the back of the host vehicle. The host vehicle may analyze the images to predict a future path of the object and/or a future location of the object. Accordingly, the host vehicle may predict whether the object will travel in an area outside of the field of view of the rear-facing camera. In some embodiments, the host vehicle may further predict a behavior of the object while outside of the field of view. For example, the host vehicle may predict whether a vehicle will change lanes or perform other maneuvers outside of the field of view. In some embodiments, the prediction may be based on information captured by other sensors, such as through analysis of images captured by a front-facing camera. For example, in some embodiments, the prediction may be based on analysis of images captured by at least one front-facing camera and at least one rear-facing camera. These examples are described in further detail below. Accordingly, these predictions may allow the host vehicle to determine navigation actions based on an object even while the object is outside of the field of view of the cameras of the host vehicle.

FIGS. 27A, 27B, and 27C illustrate example environments for predicting blind spot incursions by a host vehicle 2710. FIG. 27A illustrates an example scenario in which host vehicle 2710 may predict whether an object will travel outside of a field of view of a rear-facing camera, consistent with the disclosed embodiments. Host vehicle 2710 may be configured to capture one or more images, as described in various embodiments above. Host vehicle 2710 may correspond to vehicle 200 and may capture images using image acquisition unit 120. Accordingly, any of the embodiments or descriptions above with respect to vehicle 200 or other host vehicles may similarly apply to host vehicle 2170. For example, host vehicle 2710 may include a processor, such as processing unit 110, which may perform some or all of the operations disclosed herein.

As shown in FIG. 27A, host vehicle 2710 may be equipped with a rear-facing camera 2712, which may have a field of view 2714. Rear-facing camera 2712 may be any form of device capable of capturing images from the environment of host vehicle 2710. For example, rear-facing camera 2712 may correspond to one of image capture devices 122, 124, and 126, as described in greater detail above. Rear-facing camera 2712 may be mounted on a bumper of host vehicle 2710, or any other suitable location for viewing a region to the rear of host vehicle 2710. Rear-facing camera 2712 may be installed during manufacture of the host vehicle or added to the host vehicle as an aftermarket item. Field of view 2714 of rear-facing camera 2712 is shown by way of example and may have a variety of field of view angles (e.g., 90 degrees, 120 degrees, 180 degrees, etc.). The smaller the field of view angle, the larger the blind spot of host vehicle 2710 may be. As the size of the host vehicle blind spot increases, the greater the importance of being able to predict one or more behaviors of objects located in the blind spot of the host vehicle may be. In some embodiments, host vehicle 2710 may be a vehicle with an obscured view, and a driver or autonomous (or partially autonomous) driving system may rely on rear-facing camera 2712 to see behind host vehicle 2710. For example, host vehicle 2710 may be a truck without a rear window or with an obscured window (e.g., a flatbed truck carrying a load, etc.). In some embodiments, host vehicle 2710 may not have an obscured view but may at least partially rely on rear-facing camera 2712 for navigation. Accordingly, host vehicle 2710 is not limited to any particular type of vehicle.

Host vehicle 2710 may derive from images captured by rear-facing camera 2712 a representation of an object behind host vehicle 2710. For example, host vehicle 2710 may detect vehicle 2720 within field of view 2714. While vehicle 2720 is provided as an example object, the disclosed embodiments may be used with any object in the environment of host vehicle 2710 that may move relative to host vehicle 2710. For example, the object may include another type of vehicle (e.g., a truck, motorcycle, bus, etc.), a pedestrian, a person on a non-motorized transport (e.g., a bicycle, scooter, skateboard, etc.), an animal, an obstacle (e.g., a rolling piece of debris, a shopping cart, etc.), or various other objects that may move within the environment of host vehicle 2710. Further, while FIG. 27A shows host vehicle 2710 traveling along a roadway, the disclosed embodiments are not limited to any particular scenario. For example, the disclosed embodiments may apply when host vehicle 2710 is at an intersection, in a parking lot, in an alleyway, or various other environments. In some embodiments, host vehicle 2710 may not be moving. For example, host vehicle 2710 may be stopped along a roadway (e.g., parked in a parking lane) and may predict blind spot incursions prior to reentering the roadway.

In accordance with embodiments of the present disclosure, host vehicle 2710 may be configured to determine kinematic information associated with vehicle 2720. As used herein, kinematic information may include measurements or other information pertaining to the motion of an object. For example, the kinematic information may include information indicating a position, speed, acceleration, change in acceleration, direction of travel, change in direction of travel, a travel path, momentum (e.g., based on a detected size or type of vehicle), or any other information that may describe the motion of an object. The kinematic information may be determined based on analysis of images captured by rear-facing camera 2712. For example, host vehicle 2710 detect a first position of vehicle 2720 in a first image, and a second position of vehicle 2720 in a second image. Based on a change in distance between the first and second position and an elapsed time between the first and second images, host vehicle 2710 may determine a speed of vehicle 2720. The positions may be based in relation to a landmark, such as a lane mark, sign, or other landmark within the images. In some embodiments, the positions may be determined relative to host vehicle 2710. Accordingly, the speed, position, acceleration, or other properties of host vehicle 2710 may be used in determining the kinematic information of vehicle 2720. The position of vehicle 2720 may be tracked and analyzed across many frames to determine the kinematic information. For example, by tracking vehicle 2720 across many images, the path of travel, acceleration, and other kinematic information may be determined.

Based on the kinematic information, host vehicle 2710 may predict future positions and/or behaviors of objects. For example, referring to FIG. 27A, host vehicle 2710 may predict that vehicle 2720 will travel along path 2724. Path 2724 may be determined based on the kinematic information determined for vehicle 2720. For example, host vehicle 2710 may assume that vehicle 2710 will generally maintain the same direction of travel along the center of the current lane of travel, at the same velocity and/or acceleration. Host vehicle 2710 may similarly predict a future position 2722 of vehicle 2720, which may be along path 2724, as shown. Based on the predicted path 2724 of vehicle 2720, host vehicle 2710 may determine whether vehicle 2720 will leave field of view 2714 of rear-facing camera 2712, and thus enter a blind spot of host vehicle 2710. For example, if vehicle 2720 is predicted to maintain a speed that is greater than the current speed of host vehicle 2710, host vehicle 2710 may predict that vehicle 2720 will leave field of view 2714 along path 2724. As another example, even if the speed of vehicle 2720 is less than the speed of host vehicle 2710, vehicle 2720 may still be predicted to leave field of view 2714 if vehicle 2720 is accelerating. Accordingly, any of the various types of kinematic information described above may be used to determine whether vehicle 2720 will leave field of view 2714.

In some embodiments, the prediction whether vehicle 2720 will leave field of view 2714 may be based on additional information associated with host vehicle 2710 or its environment. For example, as described above, the current speed of host vehicle 2710 may be compared to the predicted motion of vehicle 2720. In some embodiments, planned or anticipated motion of host vehicle 2710 may also be considered. For example, host vehicle 2710 may be traveling along a target trajectory of a sparse map, such as sparse map 800, as described above. Host vehicle 2710 may determine a planned motion based on the sparse map, which may be used to determine whether objects will enter a blind spot region. For example, the sparse map may indicate that host vehicle 2710 is approaching an intersection, approaching a curve, approaching a straight road portion, entering an exit ramp, entering a region with a reduced speed limit, or other route information, which may indicate host vehicle 2710 will be speeding up or slowing down. In some embodiments, the planned or anticipated motion of host vehicle 2710 may be based on images or other sensor information captured by host vehicle 2710. For example, host vehicle 2710 may identify a vehicle traveling ahead of host vehicle 2710, which may indicate that vehicle 2710 will decelerate and maintain a velocity equal to or less than the forward vehicle to avoid a collision. The planned or anticipated motion of host vehicle 2710 may thus be used to determine whether vehicle 2720 will leave field of view 2714.

In some embodiments, the system may predict one or more behaviors of the detected object while in the area outside of the field of view of available cameras. For example, based on detected kinematics (e.g., speed, acceleration and/or direction of travel) and positioning with respect to host vehicle 2710, the system may predict, for example, how long the detected object is expected to remain in the blind spot, what position relative to the host vehicle the detected object is expected to emerge from the host vehicle blind spot, whether the detected object is expected to merge into a lane adjacent to the host vehicle, whether the detected object is expected to merge into a lane occupied by the host vehicle, whether the detected object is expected to take and exit lane or coming from an exit lane merge into the host vehicle's lane, a speed at which the object is expected to emerge from the host vehicle blind spot, or any other parameter associated with the host vehicle.

Referring to FIG. 27A, host vehicle 2710 may predict the behavior of vehicle 2720 while outside of field of view 2714. In some embodiments, this may include determining a position of the object when it will reemerge in the field of view of available cameras. In some embodiments, this may include determining a position in which the object will enter a field of view of another camera, such as field of view 2716, which may be associated with a front-facing camera of host vehicle 2710. For example, based on path 2724 and the kinematic information of vehicle 2720, host vehicle 2710 may determine a position 2722 in which vehicle 2720 will enter field of view 2716. As another example, vehicle 2720 may be determined to have a sufficient velocity to carry vehicle 2720 out of field of view 2714, but with a deceleration such that vehicle 2720 is not predicted to enter field of view 2716. Accordingly, host vehicle 2710 may predict that vehicle 2720 will reemerge into field of view 2714.

In some embodiments, host vehicle 2710 may further determine a predicted time that vehicle 2720 is expected to remain in the blind spot. For example, based on the predicted behavior of vehicle 2720, host vehicle 2710 may determine a duration 2730 representing the time it will take for vehicle 2720 to enter field of view 2716 after leaving field of view 2714. Duration 2730 may be determined based on the kinematic information for vehicle 2720 and known properties of host vehicle 2710. For example, duration 2730 may be determined based on a predicted velocity and/or acceleration of host vehicle 2720 after leaving field of view 2714 and a known distance between field of view 2714 and field of view 2716 at a given lateral distance from host vehicle 2710. Duration 2730 may also account for other predicted actions of vehicle 2720, such as changing lanes within the blind spot, as described below with respect to FIGS. 27B and 27C. It may be important for the navigation system of host vehicle 2710 to minimize duration 2730 to avoid potential collisions with vehicle 2720. Accordingly, host vehicle 2710 may implement navigation actions to minimize duration 2730. For example, this may include applying a brake, changing lanes, accelerating, or any other maneuver that may reduce duration 2730. Additional details regarding navigation actions to minimize duration 2730 are provided below. Host vehicle 2710 may further predict a speed of vehicle 2721 when it emerges from the blind spot.

According to some embodiments of the present disclosure, host vehicle 2710 may be configured to determine whether vehicle 2720 is predicted to change lanes while outside of field of view 2714. FIG. 27B illustrates an example scenario in which vehicle 2720 is expected to merge into a lane adjacent to host vehicle 2710, consistent with the disclosed embodiments. For example, in this case, predicted path 2724 may indicate that vehicle 2720 is predicted to move to a position 2722, which may be in a lane adjacent to host vehicle 2710, as shown. In some embodiments, this may be determined based on the kinematics of vehicle 2710. For example, the velocity of vehicle 2720 may have a component in a direction towards host vehicle 2710, which may indicate it is merging into the adjacent lane. Additional cues may be obtained by the cameras onboard the host vehicle and/or using any other sensor(s) onboard the vehicle, including for example, detecting of a blinking light indicating intention to change lanes, detecting a facing direction of a driver's face indicating intention to change lanes or maintain current course, or other cues, as described further below.

In some embodiments, path 2724 may be based on contextual cues from the environment of host vehicle 2710. For example, the system may detect an obstacle, such as vehicle 2740 in the same lane as vehicle 2720, which may indicate that vehicle 2720 is likely to change lanes. For example, vehicle 2740 may be determined to have a speed that is less than vehicle 2720. In order to avoid a collision with vehicle 2740, vehicle 2720 may need to decelerate or move into the adjacent lane. Host vehicle 2710 may be configured to assume that vehicle 2720 will change lanes, which may be indicate that host vehicle should not move into the adjacent lane or should do so with caution. The kinematic information for vehicle 2740 may be determined in a similar manner as kinematic information for vehicle 2720. For example, the system may analyze images captured by cameras of host vehicle 2710, as described above. In some embodiments, vehicle 2740 may also be outside of field of view 2714 and 2716. Accordingly, a predicted speed and position of vehicle 2740, determined when vehicle 2740 was within field of view 2714 or 2716, may be used to predict the pat of vehicle 2720.

As another example, the system may determine that a lane that vehicle 2720 is travelling in is ending or does not continue along the road segment. In some embodiments, this may be based on analysis of images captured by host vehicle 2710. For example, the system may detect a road mark, such as merge arrow 2742, a road sign, or another feature that may indicate that the lane is ending. In some embodiments, this may be based on map data, such as sparse map 800, which may indicate that the lane ends. Accordingly, in conjunction with the determined kinematic information, vehicle 2720 may be expected to merge into the adjacent lane. Various other contextual cues may be used to determine that vehicle 2720 will change lanes. For example, the system may analyze images captured by host vehicle 2710 to determine that vehicle 2720 has its turn signal on, that a driver of vehicle 2720 is turning to look in a blind spot of vehicle 2720, or various other contextual cues.

FIG. 27C illustrates an example scenario in which vehicle 2720 is expected to merge into a lane occupied by host vehicle 2710, consistent with the disclosed embodiments. For example, the system may detect vehicle 2720 in a lane 2750 adjacent to the current lane of travel 2752. Vehicle 2720 may be predicted to move into lane 2716 as shown by path 2724. As described above, this may be based on the kinematic information for vehicle 2720. For example, vehicle 2720 may have a speed component in the direction of vehicle 2710, which may indicate that vehicle 2720 is planning to merge into lane 2750 (either ahead of or behind host vehicle 2710). As another example, the prediction may be based on a detected increasing acceleration of vehicle 2720 determined based on analysis of images captured by the rear-facing camera. Similarly, if vehicle 2720 is detected as moving with sufficient velocity to carry vehicle 2720 into a blind spot of the host vehicle, but with a decreasing acceleration, then the navigation system of host vehicle 2710 may predict that while vehicle 2720 travels in the blind spot of host vehicle 2710, vehicle 2720 will continue to slow down and will reemerge into field of view 2714 at a certain time, and attempt a merge maneuver into lane 2752 at a location behind host vehicle 2710. These scenarios are provided by way of example, and it is to be understood that various other scenarios may be assessed to determine that vehicle 2720 will merge into lane 2752.

In some embodiments, the prediction may be based on contextual cues from the environment of host vehicle 2710. For example, although not shown in FIG. 27C, the system may detect an obstacle in lane 2750 or that lane 2750 is ending, which may indicate that vehicle 2720 is likely to merge into lane 2752. In some embodiments, this may include determining that lane 2750 is an acceleration lane. As used herein, an acceleration lane may refer to a lane or other area along a road segment to allow vehicles to accelerate before merging with through-traffic flow. Such an acceleration lane may be identified through analysis of images captured by rear-facing camera 2712. In some embodiments, the acceleration lane identification may be identified and/or confirmed based on images captured by a forward-facing camera. For example, the system may determine that lane 2750 detected from the rear-facing camera merges with lane 2752 at a position ahead of the host vehicle. As another example, the front facing camera may detect merge arrow 2754 or other features along the road segment which may indicate lane 275) is an acceleration lane. Similarly, the acceleration lane may be identified and/or confirmed based on available map information, such as sparse map 800.

According to some embodiments, the prediction of whether vehicle 2720 will leave field of view 2714 and the predicted behavior of vehicle 2720 may be based on a trained system, such as a machine learning model, which is trained to predict future vehicle locations based on received images. For example, a machine learning model may be trained using a training data set of images with associated future vehicle locations. For example, images containing a vehicle captured from a rear-facing camera may be associated with images captured from a font- or side-facing camera including the vehicle after it leaves a field of view of the rear-facing camera. The machine learning model may then be trained based on kinematic information of the vehicle indicated in the rear-facing camera images to predict the future locations. As a result, the trained system may be configured to predict whether vehicle 2720 will leave field of view 2714, the duration vehicle 2720 is outside of field of view 2714 (or the field of view of other cameras), the behavior of vehicle 2720 while outside of field of view 2714, and any other predictions for vehicle 2720 described herein.

In some embodiments, the system may be configured to predict future vehicle positions based on road vector field information. This may include capturing images captured by an image capture device of a host vehicle, such as a rear- or front-facing camera, and analyzing one or more pixels within the captured image to generate a predicted or estimated path at various points within the image. Additional details regarding the determination of estimated vehicle paths based on pixels in an image can be found in PCT International Application No. PCT/IB2020/000413, which is incorporated herein by reference in its entirety and is assigned to the same assignee as the present application.

Based on the determination of whether an object will enter a blind spot region of host vehicle 2710 and/or the predicted behavior of the object within the region, the navigation system may be configured to implement one or more control actions. A control action may be any action associated with the vehicle taken in response to a detected condition. In some examples, the control action may include determining and implementing a navigation action for host vehicle 2710. A navigation action may include any action related to the movement of the vehicle, such as one or more of a steering, braking, or acceleration of the vehicle. For example, based on a determination that vehicle 2720 is predicted to merge into lane 2752 occupied by host vehicle 2710, the vehicle navigation system may cause host vehicle 2710 to maintain its current speed, accelerate to facilitate a merge of vehicle 2720 behind the host vehicle, decelerate to facilitate a merge of vehicle 2720 ahead of the host vehicle, or the like. In some cases, the host vehicle navigation system may cause a change in the steering system of host vehicle 2710. For example, the navigation action may cause host vehicle 2710 to change lanes. Such a change in lanes may be based, for example, on a prediction that while in the vehicle blind spot, the vehicle 2720 may be expected to drive next to host vehicle 2710 (e.g., where there is insufficient space ahead of or behind host vehicle 2710 to allow vehicle 2720 to merge). Accordingly, if lane 2750 is an acceleration lane, host vehicle 2710 may move into an adjacent lane to allow vehicle 2720 to merge. In some embodiments, the navigation action may be to prevent a steering action. For example, based on the intended destination for host vehicle 2710, the navigation system may plan to implement a lane change or other maneuver to follow the planned trajectory. However, if vehicle 2720 is predicted to travel next to host vehicle 2710 while in the blind spot, the navigation system may prevent or delay the lane change maneuver and maintain the current direction of travel.

Various other control actions may be performed based on the predicted blind spot incursion. In some embodiments, one or more warnings may be issued to the occupants of host vehicle 2710. Such warnings may indicate, for example, the presence of an object in a blind spot of the host vehicle. Such warnings, however, may also indicate one or more expected actions of vehicle 2720 while in the blind spot of host vehicle 2710. For example, the warning may indicate a vehicle, bicycle, pedestrian or other object is present in the blind spot and is expected to merge ahead/behind the host vehicle, or the like. The warnings to the occupants of the vehicle may include one or more illuminated lights, a text message on a display screen/heads up display, a graphical message on a display screen/heads up display, an audible tone, a spoken message, a message transmitted to an auxiliary device (e.g., a mobile phone, etc.), or any other form of alert.

While the disclosed embodiments above are described with respect to a rear-facing camera, in some embodiments, a front-facing camera may be used to detect objects in a blind spot region ahead of host vehicle 2710. For example, host vehicle 2710 may be a tall vehicle with an extended hood portion, such as a school bus, such that a driver may not be able to see what's directly in front of the front hood/bumper area of the bus (e.g., the driver may not be able to see a child in this area). A wide-angle camera may be mounted on a front portion (e.g., a hood area/grill area/front tip) of host vehicle 2710. The wide-angle camera may also be mounted on any other type of vehicle otherwise having a blind spot forward of the vehicle.

The vehicle navigation system may be configured receive one or more images captured by the front-facing camera and analyze the one or more images to detect the presence of an object (e.g., a person) in front of host vehicle 2710, especially where the object is located in a blind spot of the host vehicle that may not be visible to an operator and/or occupant of host vehicle 2710. In response to detecting an object in this area the system may cause at least one warning or alarm to be issued based on detection of such an object. The warning may include an audio or visual warning (e.g., one or more illuminated lights, graphics or text on a display, tones, spoken message, etc.), as described above. Additionally, or alternatively, the at least one processor may be associated with a navigation system for the host vehicle and may cause one or more navigational actions in response to an object detected in a blind spot forward of the host vehicle. For example, in response to a detected person in a blind spot forward of the host vehicle, the processor may cause at least one navigational actuation system of the host vehicle to cause a change in navigation of the host vehicle (e.g., apply a brake of the host vehicle to slow and/or stop the host vehicle or to prevent the host vehicle from moving; change a steering direction of the host vehicle, or similar navigational actions).

FIG. 28 is a flowchart showing an example process 2800 for predicting blind spot incursions, consistent with the disclosed embodiments. Process 2800 may be performed by at least one processing device of a host vehicle, such as processing unit 110, as described above. It is to be understood that throughout the present disclosure, the term “processor” is used as a shorthand for “at least one processor.” In other words, a processor may include one or more structures that perform logic operations whether such structures are collocated, connected, or disbursed. In some embodiments, a non-transitory computer readable medium may contain instructions that when executed by a processor cause the processor to perform process 2800. Further, process 2800 is not necessarily limited to the steps shown in FIG. 28, and any steps or processes of the various embodiments described throughout the present disclosure may also be included in process 2800, including those described above with respect to FIGS. 27A-27C.

In step 2810, process 2800 may include receiving, from an image capture device located on a rear of a host vehicle, at least one image representative of an environment of the host vehicle. For example, the navigation system for host vehicle 2710 may receive an image captured by rear-facing camera 2712, as described above. The image capture device may be mounted on a rear bumper of the host vehicle, or any other suitable position for capturing images from a region behind the host vehicle.

In step 2820, process 2800 may include analyzing the at least one image to identify an object in the environment of the host vehicle. In some embodiments, the object may comprise a target vehicle traveling along a road segment in which the host vehicle is traveling. For example, the navigation system of host vehicle 2710 may analyze images captured by rear-facing camera 2712 to identify vehicle 2720. The object is not limited to a vehicle, however, and may include a pedestrian, a bicycle, a scooter, a road obstacle, or other objects as described in greater detail above.

In step 2830, process 2800 may include analyzing the at least one image to determine kinematic information associated with the object. As described above, the kinematic information may include any information pertaining to the motion of the object. For example, the kinematic information may include at least one of a speed, acceleration, a size, or a direction of travel of the object. The kinematic information may be determined by tracking the position of the object over multiple images, as described in further detail above. The position of the object may be tracked relative to the host vehicle, relative to a landmark or other feature in the environment of the host vehicle, or relative to other suitable reference points.

In step 2840, process 2800 may include predicting, based on the kinematic information, that the object will travel in area region outside of a field of view of the image capture device. For example, the navigation system for host vehicle 2710 may predict whether vehicle 2720 will travel outside of field of view 2714. Accordingly, the region may be defined as the region between field of view 2714 and field of view 2716, or any other region excluding field of view 2714. As an illustrative example, vehicle 2720 may be determined to be traveling at a speed that is greater than the speed of host vehicle 2710, which may indicate that vehicle 2720 will leave field of view 2714. In some embodiments, the prediction may further depend on other information associated with the host vehicle or the environment of the host vehicle. For example, the prediction may account for the current speed, direction of travel, acceleration, change in acceleration, or other kinematic properties of the host vehicle. In some embodiments, the prediction may account for planned or anticipated actions of the host vehicle. For example, the navigation system may access map information to determine whether the host vehicle will accelerate, decelerate, change lanes, or perform other navigational actions based on the planned route for the host vehicle. In some embodiments, the prediction may account for contextual cues within the environment of the host vehicle. For example, the host vehicle may detect a vehicle or other obstacle in the same lane as the host vehicle or the object, which may indicate that the host vehicle or the object will slow down, change lanes, or perform another navigation action that may affect whether the object will leave the field of view of the rear-facing camera.

In some embodiments, process 2800 may further include predicting, based on the kinematic information, a behavior of the object while in the region outside of the field of view. For example, this may include determining a duration in which the object is expected to remain in the region outside of the field of view. This may include determining a position and/or speed at which the object is expected to reemerge within the field of view of one or more cameras mounted on host vehicle 2710. Accordingly, process 2800 may include determining a position of the object relative to the host vehicle in which the object is expected to enter at least one of the field of view of the image capture device or a field of view of an additional image capture device mounted on the host vehicle. In some embodiments, predicting the behavior of the object may comprise determining whether the object is expected to merge into a lane adjacent to the host vehicle while in the region outside of the field of view, as described in further detail above with respect to FIG. 27B. As another example, predicting the behavior of the object may comprise determining whether the object is expected to merge into a lane occupied by the host vehicle while in the region outside of the field of view, as described in further detail above with respect to FIG. 27C.

In some embodiments, process 2800 may include determining, based on the at least one image, a lane of travel of the object. This may include identifying a lane type of the lane of travel of the object, such as whether the lane of travel is an acceleration lane, a merge lane, a turn lane, a passing lane, or other lane type that may indicate a behavior of the object while outside of the field of view of the camera. Accordingly, predicting the behavior of the object may further be based on the lane of travel. In some embodiments, process 2800 may further include confirming the lane of travel. The lane of travel may be confirmed based on at least one additional image captured by a front-facing image capture device of the host vehicle, based on map data, or any other indication of the lane of travel, as described in further detail above.

In step 2850, process 2800 may include performing a control action based on the prediction. This may include the prediction of whether the object will travel in a region outside of the field of view of the image capture device, the predicted behavior of the object while outside of the field of view, or both. In some embodiments, the control action may include providing a warning indicating the object is expected to travel in the region outside of a field of view of the image capture device. As another example, the control action may include providing a warning indicating the predicted behavior of the object while outside of the field of view of the image capture device. The providing the warning may comprise at least one of illuminating a light, displaying a text message, displaying a graphical message, presenting an audible tone, or presenting a spoken message, as described above. The warning may be displayed on a heads-up display (HUD), a display screen, or other interface device within the host vehicle.

In some embodiments, the control action may comprise determining a navigational action for the host vehicle. The control action may further comprise causing the host vehicle to implement the navigational action. For example, the navigation action may include braking maneuver, an acceleration maneuver, a lane change maneuver, or a combination of one or more of these maneuvers. In some embodiments, the navigation action may be to maintain a current speed, acceleration, direction of travel, or other properties. As described above, process 2800 may include determining a duration in which the object is expected to remain in the region outside of the field of view. For example, process 2800 may include determining duration 2730, as described above. In such embodiments, the control action may comprise causing the host vehicle to implement a navigation action to reduce the duration, which may mitigate potential collisions with the vehicle while in the blind spot. For example, the navigational action may comprise a braking maneuver, which may reduce the speed of the host vehicle to allow the object to enter the field of view of a front-facing camera sooner. As another example, the navigational action may comprise an acceleration maneuver, which may cause the object to reemerge in the field of view of the rear-facing camera sooner. In another example, if the object is expected to continue to travel next to the host vehicle within the blind spot, the navigation action may include maintaining a current speed, accelerating, decelerating, and/or changing lanes to facilitate a merge maneuver of the object. In some embodiments, the determined navigational action may also be based, at least in part, on rules or policies governing the navigational actions of the host vehicle. For example, driving policies may ensure that the actions considered or selected by the host vehicle to minimize the duration comply with rules or policies related to driving safety, passenger comfort, traffic laws or regulations, or various other types of rules or policies. The disclosed embodiments are not limited to any particular form of control action and the control action may include any action responsive to the predictions described above.

The foregoing description has been presented for purposes of illustration. It is not exhaustive and is not limited to the precise forms or embodiments disclosed. Modifications and adaptations will be apparent to those skilled in the art from consideration of the specification and practice of the disclosed embodiments. Additionally, although aspects of the disclosed embodiments are described as being stored in memory, one skilled in the art will appreciate that these aspects can also be stored on other types of computer readable media, such as secondary storage devices, for example, hard disks or CD ROM, or other forms of RAM or ROM, USB media, DVD. Blu-ray, 4K Ultra HD Blu-ray, or other optical drive media.

Computer programs based on the written description and disclosed methods are within the skill of an experienced developer. The various programs or program modules can be created using any of the techniques known to one skilled in the art or can be designed in connection with existing software. For example, program sections or program modules can be designed in or by means of .Net Framework, .Net Compact Framework (and related languages, such as Visual Basic, C, etc.), Java, C++, Objective-C, HTML, HTML/AJAX combinations, XML, or HTML with included Java applets.

Moreover, while illustrative embodiments have been described herein, the scope of any and all embodiments having equivalent elements, modifications, omissions, combinations (e.g., of aspects across various embodiments), adaptations and/or alterations as would be appreciated by those skilled in the art based on the present disclosure. The limitations in the claims are to be interpreted broadly based on the language employed in the claims and not limited to examples described in the present specification or during the prosecution of the application. The examples are to be construed as non-exclusive. Furthermore, the steps of the disclosed methods may be modified in any manner, including by reordering steps and/or inserting or deleting steps. It is intended, therefore, that the specification and examples be considered as illustrative only, with a true scope and spirit being indicated by the following claims and their full scope of equivalents.

claim.claim-text: 1. A system for predicting blind spot incursions, the system comprising:at least one processor comprising circuitry and a memory, wherein the memory includes instructions that when executed by the circuitry cause the at least one processor to:receive at least one image acquired by an image capture device located on a rear of a host vehicle, the at least one image being representative of an environment of the host vehicle;analyze the at least one image to identify an object in the environment of the host vehicle;analyze the at least one image to determine kinematic information associated with the object;predict, based on the kinematic information, that the object will travel in a region outside of a field of view of the image capture device; andperform a control action based on the prediction.
2. The system of claim 1, wherein the image capture device is mounted on a rear bumper of the host vehicle.
3. The system of claim 1, wherein the kinematic information includes at least one of a speed, acceleration, a size, or a direction of travel of the object.
4. The system of claim 1, wherein the object comprises a target vehicle traveling along a road segment in which the host vehicle is traveling.
5. The system of claim 1, wherein performing the control action comprises determining a navigational action for the host vehicle.
6. The system of claim 5, wherein performing the control action further comprises causing the host vehicle to implement the navigational action.
7. The system of claim 5, wherein the navigational action comprises at least one of a braking maneuver, an acceleration maneuver, or a lane change maneuver.

8. The system of claim 1, wherein the memory further includes instructions that when executed by the circuitry cause the at least one processor to predict, based on the kinematic information, a behavior of the object while in the region outside of the field of view.
9. The system of claim 8, wherein predicting the behavior of the object comprises determining a duration in which the object is expected to remain in the region outside of the field of view.
10. The system of claim 9, wherein performing the control action comprises causing the host vehicle to implement a navigation action to reduce the duration.
11. The system of claim 10, wherein the navigational action comprises at least one of a braking maneuver or an acceleration maneuver.

12. The system of claim 8, wherein predicting the behavior of the object comprises determining a position of the object relative to the host vehicle in which the object is expected to enter at least one of the field of view of the image capture device or a field of view of an additional image capture device mounted on the host vehicle.

13. The system of claim 8, wherein predicting the behavior of the object comprises determining whether the object is expected to merge into a lane adjacent to the host vehicle while in the region outside of the field of view.

14. The system of claim 8, wherein predicting the behavior of the object comprises determining whether the object is expected to merge into a lane occupied by the host vehicle while in the region outside of the field of view.

15. The system of claim 8, wherein the memory further includes instructions that when executed by the circuitry cause the at least one processor to determine, based on the at least one image, a lane of travel of the object, and wherein predicting the behavior of the object is further based on the lane of travel.

16. The system of claim 15, wherein the memory further includes instructions that when executed by the circuitry cause the at least one processor to confirm the lane of travel based on at least one additional image captured by a front-facing image capture device of the host vehicle.
17. The system of claim 1, wherein the control action comprises providing a warning indicating the object is expected to travel in the region outside of the field of view of the image capture device.

18. The system of claim 17, wherein providing the warning comprises at least one of illuminating a light, displaying a text message, displaying a graphical message, presenting an audible tone, or presenting a spoken message.

19. A computer-implemented method for predicting blind spot incursions, the method comprising:receiving at least one image acquired by an image capture device located on a rear of a host vehicle, the at least one image being representative of an environment of the host vehicle;analyzing the at least one image to identify an object in the environment of the host vehicle;analyzing the at least one image to determine kinematic information associated with the object;predicting, based on the kinematic information, that the object will travel in area region outside of a field of view of the image capture device; andperforming a control action based on the prediction.
20. The method of claim 19, wherein the image capture device is mounted on a rear bumper of the host vehicle.
21. The method of claim 19, wherein the kinematic information includes at least one of a speed, acceleration, a size, or a direction of travel of the object.
22. The method of claim 19, wherein the method further comprises predicting, based on the kinematic information, a behavior of the object while in the region outside of the field of view.
23. The method of claim 22, wherein predicting the behavior of the object comprises determining a duration in which the object is expected to remain in the region outside of the field of view.
24. The method of claim 23, wherein performing the control action comprises causing the host vehicle to implement a navigation action to reduce the duration.
25. The method of claim 24, wherein the navigational action comprises at least one of a braking maneuver or an acceleration maneuver.

26. The method of claim 22, wherein predicting the behavior of the object comprises determining a position of the object relative to the host vehicle in which the object is expected to enter at least one of the field of view of the image capture device or a field of view of an additional image capture device mounted on the host vehicle.

27. The method of claim 22, wherein predicting the behavior of the object comprises determining whether the object is expected to merge into a lane adjacent to the host vehicle while in the region outside of the field of view.

28. The method of claim 22, wherein predicting the behavior of the object comprises determining whether the object is expected to merge into a lane occupied by the host vehicle while in the region outside of the field of view.

29. The method of claim 22, wherein the method further comprises determining, based on the at least one image, a lane of travel of the object, and wherein predicting the behavior of the object is further based on the lane of travel.
30. The method of claim 19, wherein the control action comprises providing a warning indicating object is expected to travel in the region outside of a field of view of the image capture device.

31. A non-transitory computer-readable medium storing instructions that, when executed by at least one processor, are configured to cause at least one processor to perform a method for predicting blind spot incursions, the method comprising:receiving at least one image acquired by an image capture device located on a rear of a host vehicle, the at least one image being representative of an environment of the host vehicle;analyzing the at least one image to identify an object in the environment of the host vehicle;analyzing the at least one image to determine kinematic information associated with the object;predicting, based on the kinematic information, that the object will travel in area region outside of a field of view of the image capture device; andperforming a control action based on the prediction.
